entry.title: danricho/where_the
entry.summary:
A simple Python Flask web application which helps keep track of your stored items.

Where The ?!?

A simple Python Flask web application which helps keep track of your stored items.

Features

  • Responsive web-based user interface
  • Easy, simple location editing
  • Search by stored item
  • Sort locations by different attributes:
    • description
    • location (eg. Office, Garage, etc)
    • type (eg. Shelf, Plastic Box, etc)
    • recently edited
    • unique ID
    • how used (% full)
  • QR codes to assist location tracking based on unique ID
  • Print QR code labels from website
  • Simple JSON storage (pros & cons)

Screenshots - Out of date already!

Does anyone know a quick way to generate this type of demo image?

Home Page

Note that QR scanning is available on mobile phones / tablets only - due to my design decision for simplicity.

Viewing a Location

Update and more pages coming soon

Installation - Native Python

These steps describe how I set it up. I use a linux terminal so under Windows there may be minor step inaccuracies.

  1. Clone repo to a local directory. eg: git clone https://github.com/danricho/where_the.git where_the

  2. Create a Python Virtual Environment (venv). eg: python3 -m venv venv

  3. Install dependencies via pip into your venv. eg: venv/bin/pip install -r requirements.txt or activate venv then pip install -r requirements.txt

  4. Create config.yml and update according it to your setup - see the Configuration section.

  5. Run main.py in your venv. eg: venv/bin/python main.py or activate venv then python main.py

Installation - Docker Compose

Running in Docker is a quick way to get this to run as a service (launches on boot etc).

  1. Clone repo to a local directory. eg: git clone https://github.com/danricho/where_the.git where_the

  2. Create config.yml and update according to the Configuration section. This file is mounted within the docker image but saved here outside it (to keep data between docker sessions)

  3. Create data.json and set the content to {}. This file is mounted within the docker image but saved here outside it (to keep data between docker sessions)

  4. Run the docker container using the command docker-compose up -d.

  5. To troubleshoot the container it may help to see it's logs: docker logs where_the

Configuration (config.yml)

PRIMARY-COLOR: '#C0A890'
DISABLE-QR-LOGO: false

FLASK: # These are Flask configuration settings
  HOST: 0.0.0.0
  PORT: '5000'
  SECRET: abcd1234 
  DEBUG: false
  TEMPLATES_AUTO_RELOAD: true
  USE_RELOADER: false
  LOGIN_DISABLED: false # this one disables authentication (login access control)

SITE:
  BASE_URL: http://localhost # this is your domain or start of your url 
  PATH_PREFIX: / # this is useful if you want a prefix on the url path

USERS: # users for flask-login - will be updated with settings... eg: if you change your sorting
  1:
    username: user
    password: pass
  2:
    username: user2
    password: pass

What's Next / Future Improvements

I plan to start using it more to identify the holes I haven't found yet!
I do have a few ideas that I'd like to add while maintaining the current simplicity as much as possible.

Please propose and discuss ideas here!

My ideas so far (most would be choosen via a config.yml option):â€‹

  • Add Dark Mode to Chota CSS, which is very easy (as per the Chota webpage) and a toggle for it in the fixed header
  • Add additional storage options other than raw JSON file - discussion
  • Improve Flask-Login implementation - discussion
  • UI improvements - discussion
  • Code improvements - discussion

I welcome contributions to these with Pull requests!

Change Log

See changelog for a history of changes.
